Award.AbstractNarration:
Species are delineated on the basis of their shared evolutionary histories, but whenever they have been examined in detail, they show variation across their ranges. If this variation represents fine-scale adaptation to local conditions, adaptation at the overall species level may be hindered. The project entails examining this issue by characterizing the evolutionary patterns in snake venoms across and within species. Snake venoms are ideal for studying adaptation because of their evolutionarily significant roles in feeding and defense and their potential for specialization for local prey species. The venoms of 10 species of snake native to the United States will be completely characterized by cutting-edge molecular techniques for study of species-level adaptive evolution, and venom variation within three of these species will be quantified for study of fine-scale adaptation.

This research will provide an unprecedented characterization of snake venoms and their geographic variation for some of the most medically significant species native to the United States, contributing to our understanding of adaptive evolution. Snakebites cause an estimated 125,000 deaths per year worldwide, and the development and improvement of treatments for them will benefit from this detailed molecular characterization of venom composition. Because of the targets of snake-venom toxins and their shared ancestry with proteins involved in basic biological processes and human disease, the results of the project could strongly influence drug design and treatment for pain, inflammation, arthritis, cancer, heart attacks, and strokes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Patterns of phenotypic variation within and between species result from complex interactions between demographics, genetic drift, gene flow (e.g., migration), and selection. Although these interactions have been investigated extensively theoretically, predictions of evolutionary outcomes vary widely. For example, migration is expected to homogenize populations, preventing divergence, but, in certain scenarios, such as in inbred populations, migration can increase genetic variation upon which selection can act, thereby promoting divergence. A trait’s genetic architecture can also determine its rate and mechanism of evolution. Most complex traits, however, emerge from genetics beyond our current means of delineation. This project investigated patterns and processes related to the intraspecific evolution of a complex phenotype, snake venom, with tractable genetics and critical contribution to fitness.

Snake venoms function in defense and in killing and digesting prey and typically consist of 50-100 protein components. This project began with the development of high-throughput approaches to the characterization of venom genes and the assessment of their expression and sequence variation. We developed and implemented genomic, transcriptomic, and proteomic techniques for complete characterizations of hundreds of individual venoms from six species of venomous snake native to the United States: the Timber Rattlesnake (Crotalus horridus), the Eastern Diamondback Rattlesnake (Crotalus adamanteus), the Rock Rattlesnake (Crotalus lepidus), the Pygmy Rattlesnake (Sistrurus miliarius), the Cottonmouth (Agkistrodon piscivorus), and the Eastern Coralsnake (Micrurus fulvius). We provided the first high-throughput, complete venom characterizations for the three major families of venomous snakes (Viperidae, Elapidae, and Colubridae) and confirmed the significant role of positive (i.e., Darwinian) selection in the divergence of the venom phenotype between species.

After establishing methodology, the project shifted to the characterization of patterns of phenotypic, expression, and sequence variation with species. Although most species showed significant venom expression differences among populations, the Eastern Coralsnake showed no evidence of differentiation among populations; intraspecific variation was widespread for venoms, but not universal. Adults and juveniles of some, but not all, species had significantly different venom compositions, and patterns of expression divergence within species could be different for adults and juveniles, indicating that selection may differ with age. Venom compositional divergence among populations generally corresponded to measurable functional differentiation in venoms, and, in some cases, venom compositional differences among populations also corresponded to differences in head morphology and fang length. Venom is therefore not a completely modular phenotype, but is instead likely integrated with general morphological features related to feeding.

The primary patterns that emerged from our analyses were that venom divergence was rapid among populations within species and that divergence occurred primarily by means of changes in the amounts of venom components (i.e., expression levels) rather than changes to their sequences, particularly over short time scales. Where examined, sequence variation was present in venom genes, but this variation did not correspond with differences among populations. In at least some species, the most rapid changes in expression levels across populations were confined to those venom components expressed at low levels; highly expressed toxins appear to have expression levels under stronger purifying selection. Copy-number variation was found to be an important source of genetic variation for venom composition within species, and selection for increased expression may promote gene-family origin and expansion by favoring more copies of individual toxins. Expression levels may be more amenable to rapid evolutionary change because more genetic mechanisms exist for changing expression levels than for changing protein function, making expression a larger mutational target and therefore more likely to show genetic variation for selection to act upon.

The project provided training for one postdoctoral researcher in transcriptomic, proteomic, and genomic techniques. One graduate student was trained in bioinformatics, and four graduate students were trained in field, molecular, and bioinformatic techniques. Eight undergraduates were trained in snake husbandry and molecular techniques.
